title: Obama Meets Ethiopian Airlines CEO
text:
11 August 2015 17:28 CET Obama Meets Ethiopian Airlines CEO By Daily Guide 
President Obama (2nd left) Meets Ethiopian Airlines CEO (left) 
US President Barack Obama, Senators and House of Representatives paid a visit to Ethiopian Airlines, the largest airline in Africa during the president's three-day official visit to Ethiopia. 
President Obama visited the Ethiopian Academy and first Ethiopian B787 Dreamliner dubbed, “Africa First” and held brief discussions with Tewolde Gebre Mariam, CEO Ethiopian Airlines Group. 
He commended the long-standing and close partnership between Ethiopian and the Boeing Company. 
President Obama toured the Boeing assembly line and was gratified to see the Boeing 787 Dreamliner carrying the Ethiopian flag. 
Mr Tewolde Gebremariam briefed the President on the airline's current ownership of 13 B787 Dreamliners - with another eight on order and expressed delight with its popularity among Ethiopian's customers. 
The CEO cited Washington DC, Beijing, Shanghai, Changzhou, Hong Kong and Luanda as some of the profitable routes of the airline. 
He also told President Obama that Ethiopian is currently flying to 91 international destinations across five continents. 
Mr Tewolde stated that Ethiopian Airlines will continue its efforts for the reopening of the USA EXIM Bank, which guarantees the loans for the purchase of ET's Boeing Airplanes. 
In recognition of the historic contribution of Colonel Robinson to Ethiopia and the Ethiopian people, the CEO announced plans to name one of the incoming new airplanes after him. 
About Ethiopian Ethiopian Airlines (Ethiopian) is the fastest growing Airline in Africa. It has become one of the continent's leading carriers unrivalled in efficiency and operational success. 
Ethiopian operates the youngest and most modern fleet to more than 91 international destinations across five continents. 
Ethiopian fleet includes ultramodern and environmentally friendly aircraft such as the Boeing 787, Boeing 777-300ER, Boeing 777-200LR, Boeing 777-200 Freighter and Bombardier Q-400 with double cabin. In fact, Ethiopian is the first airline in Africa to own and operate these aircraft. 
A Business Desk report
